intro: Sisyrinchium montanum var. crebrum, commonly known as the mountain blue-eyed grass, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Iridaceae family and is characterized by its narrow, grass-like leaves and clusters of blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and rocky slopes. It produces small, tuberous roots that help it survive in harsh, arid environments. The flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies.
